autorecipes

Source: vignettes/autorecipes.Rmd
autorecipes.Rmd
library(autorecipes)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'autorecipes'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     units, weekdays
library(magrittr)

Background

Do you find yourself manually selecting the dishes you want to eat each week? autorecipes is designed to simplify and automate the laborious task of picking your weekly recipes.

Usage

Example recipes

autorecipes recipes includes a set of length(recipebook_example) example recipes stored in autorecipes::recipebook_example. Users are enabled and encouraged to add their own recipes, but the example provides a way to use and convey the benefit of autorecipes even without a user-inputted, recipe database.


recipebook <- recipebook_example

print(paste0("There are ", length(recipebook), " example recipes"))
#> [1] "There are 26 example recipes"

recipes(recipebook) %>% head()
#> # A tibble: 6 × 5
#>   index names                                       ingredients fav   last_eaten
#>   <int> <chr>                                       <list>      <lgl> <date>    
#> 1     1 Akoori Eggs with Spinach & Potato           <Ingrdnts>  FALSE NA        
#> 2     2 Crispy Duck with Fava Beans & Caramelised … <Ingrdnts>  FALSE NA        
#> 3     3 Chicken with Rosemary Plumns                <Ingrdnts>  FALSE NA        
#> 4     4 Chickpea & Sweet Potato Masala              <Ingrdnts>  FALSE NA        
#> 5     5 Gaucho Steaks with Chimichurri Salad        <Ingrdnts>  FALSE NA        
#> 6     6 Chipotle Bean Taco Salad                    <Ingrdnts>  FALSE NA

Set your favourite recipes

autorecipes allows you to set your favorite recipes. This information can be used to determine the subset of recipes that will enter your meal plan by setting autorecipes::create_meal_plan(fav_only = TRUE).


recipebook <- add_favourites(recipebook, 1:3)

recipes(recipebook) %>% head()
#> # A tibble: 6 × 5
#>   index names                                       ingredients fav   last_eaten
#>   <int> <chr>                                       <list>      <lgl> <date>    
#> 1     1 Akoori Eggs with Spinach & Potato           <Ingrdnts>  TRUE  NA        
#> 2     2 Crispy Duck with Fava Beans & Caramelised … <Ingrdnts>  TRUE  NA        
#> 3     3 Chicken with Rosemary Plumns                <Ingrdnts>  TRUE  NA        
#> 4     4 Chickpea & Sweet Potato Masala              <Ingrdnts>  FALSE NA        
#> 5     5 Gaucho Steaks with Chimichurri Salad        <Ingrdnts>  FALSE NA        
#> 6     6 Chipotle Bean Taco Salad                    <Ingrdnts>  FALSE NA

Create a meal plan

autorecipes allows you to create meal plan from your RecipeBook-class object. For this, you can set the days and meals you would like to order for. And also whether you only want to use favourite recipes.


recipebook <- create_meal_plan(
  recipebook,
  which_days = c("Wed", "Thurs", "Fri", "Sat", "Sun"), which_meals = "Dinner",
  fav_only = TRUE
)

meal_plan(recipebook)
#> # A tibble: 5 × 7
#>   day   meal   recipe_index names                   ingredients fav   last_eaten
#>   <fct> <fct>         <int> <chr>                   <list>      <lgl> <date>    
#> 1 Wed   Dinner            2 Crispy Duck with Fava … <Ingrdnts>  TRUE  2022-03-19
#> 2 Thurs Dinner            3 Chicken with Rosemary … <Ingrdnts>  TRUE  2022-03-19
#> 3 Fri   Dinner            1 Akoori Eggs with Spina… <Ingrdnts>  TRUE  2022-03-19
#> 4 Sat   Dinner            2 Crispy Duck with Fava … <Ingrdnts>  TRUE  2022-03-19
#> 5 Sun   Dinner            3 Chicken with Rosemary … <Ingrdnts>  TRUE  2022-03-19

Create shopping list 


recipebook <- create_shopping_list(recipebook, "minimal")
